name: usermod
desc: The `usermod` command line tool can be used to modify properties, permissions, and group membership of existing users.

-a.name: Add user to additional groups beyond their existing groups

-b.name: Create a new basic directory in the user's home directory

-e.name: Expiration date for the user account

-m.name: Create a new basic directory in the user's home directory

-o.name: Allow the use of non-unique user IDs

-Z.name: Set SELinux User Mapping for the user

content:
Example

  • Add user jdoe to group sales: sudo usermod -a -G sales jdoe
  • Change the home directory of user jdoe to /home/jdoe-new: sudo usermod -d /home/jdoe-new jdoe
  • Change the comment information for user jdoe to "John Doe, Engineering": sudo usermod -c "John Doe, Engineering" jdoe
  • Change the default shell for user jdoe to zsh: sudo usermod -s /bin/zsh jdoe
  • Change the UID for user jdoe to 1001: sudo usermod -u 1001 jdoe
